p: TiO 2 has attracted much attention because of its superior chemical and physical properties, and potential applications in gas sensing 1, photocatalysis 2, and lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) 3 4. TiO 2 with different polymorphs (anatase, rutile, and bronze) has been extensively studied as an alternative to the carbonaceous anode for LIBs. Anatase TiO 2 as an anode material has generated special interests owing to its high electrochemical activity, low toxicity, chemical stability, low price, and safety. Its high lithium ion insertion/extraction potential at ~1.7 V (versus Li +/Li) is inherently safe because of avoiding the Li-dendrite electroplating. Furthermore, the limited volume change (less than 4%) during the Li + insertion/extraction process leads to an enhanced structural stability and a prolonged cycling life 5. However, the poor ionic and electronic conductivity of anatase TiO 2 and the limited specific capacity (Li xTiO 2 (x≤0.5), x = 0.5, 168 mAh/g) pose challenges to meet the requirements for high-power-density and high-energy-density LIBs.
